awd_titl_txt: Models of the Nuclear Pore Biomechanics
awd_abstract_narration:
Cells in the body use many physical processes to sustain life.  Many of them depend on moving large molecules into and out of the nucleus. Such transportation is done through small and complicated pathways, called nuclear pore complexes. Despite the vital importance of the nuclear pore complex in cell biology, little is known about the mechanics and dynamics of the transport of the molecules through them. This project includes fundamental research towards understanding the biomechanics of the nuclear pore complex and transport. Understanding how molecules are actively transported through these pore will ultimately inform creation of new cell-based therapeutic approaches and potentially also create industrial applications of biomimetic artificial pores. This project crosses several disciplinary boundaries including those between biology, chemistry, mechanics, and bioengineering. The multi-disciplinary approach, along with outreach targeted to underrepresented students and student teachers, will help broaden participation of underrepresented groups in research and positively impact science, technology, engineering and mathematics education.  The research team will partner with the Berkeley NSF-supported BERET program to introduce the power of computational modeling to high school students.

The complex, yet delicate, geometry of the nuclear pore and the fine spatiotemporal resolution at which nucleocytoplasmic transport takes place have hindered the direct, experimental investigations of this mysterious nanopore. Given the limitations of experimental techniques, computational approaches spanning multiple scales can break through to understanding by simulating its activity mechanistically. Computational models offer a strong platform for capturing the nanosecond-scale interactions between transported macromolecular cargos and the nuclear pore at nanometer spatial resolutions to examine the details of nucleocytoplasmic transport phenomena. Using a combination of bioinformatics, computational biology and biophysics modeling approaches, ranging from all-atom molecular dynamics and coarse-grained Brownian dynamics to new agent-based modeling methods, this research will shed light on the structure and function of the nuclear pore complex and the dynamics of nucleocytoplasmic traffic.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA, THE

por.por_cntn:
Overview and Major Goals

 This project embarked on an ambitious journey to unravel the mysteries of cellular transport mechanisms, focusing on the nuclear pore complex (NPC)—a vital gateway for traffic between the cytoplasm and the nucleus. Developing and leveraging advanced computational models, our research aimed to illuminate the intricate processes governing the movement of macromolecules through these nanopores, providing groundbreaking insights into cellular function and opening new avenues for therapeutic and industrial applications.

Achievements and Intellectual Merit

 Innovative Modeling and Free Energy Calculations: We developed novel 3D coarse-grained and bioinformatics models to simulate the NPC and its interactions with various cargos. These models have significantly advanced our understanding of the NPC's structure and function, particularly regarding the behavior of FG-Nups, proteins essential for nucleocytoplasmic transport. Our models have additionally advanced the capability to conduct free energy calculations within the NPC. These models are instrumental in unraveling the selective barrier nature of the NPC, enhancing our understanding of how specific molecules are chosen for transport in and out of the cell nucleus.

Key Findings:

  • Polymeric Meshwork Insights: We have enhanced our understanding of the NPC's inner workings, providing new evidence in the longstanding debate over its gel-like versus brush-like internal structure.
  • Mechanotransduction and NPC Dynamics: In a pioneering study, we extended our coarse-grained models using polymer scaling theory to explore the NPC's role in mechanotransduction—a process where mechanical force is converted into biochemical signals. We discovered that the NPC's diameter expansion under force plays a critical role in regulating molecular flux into the nucleus. Our theoretical models, validated by Brownian dynamics simulations, illustrate how the transport rate through the NPC is exponentially linked to the pore size, providing invaluable insights into the molecular transport dynamics.
  • Sequence and Transport: We elucidated how the specific sequences of FG-Nups influence their conformational behavior, significantly impacting nucleocytoplasmic transport processes.
  • Control Mechanisms of mRNA Export: Our studies shed light on the complex mechanisms controlling mRNA export through the NPC, highlighting the importance of cooperative processes in this vital function.

Broader Impacts

Scientific and Industrial Advancements:

Our findings hold the potential to revolutionize understanding and manipulation of nucleocytoplasmic transport, with implications for developing new cell-based therapies and biomimetic artificial nanopores. The interdisciplinary nature of our project underscores its broad applicability and capacity to foster innovation across biology, chemistry, mechanics, and bioengineering.

Educational Impact:

The project has been instrumental in training a new generation of scientists, including graduate and undergraduate students, and postdoctoral researchers. High school STEM teachers also gained valuable research experience, particularly in computational modeling. Our findings have enriched academic courses and presentations, fostering interdisciplinary education and inspiring future research endeavors.

Conclusion

This project represents a significant step forward in our understanding of cellular mechanobiology, with profound implications for science, medicine, and industry. By bridging various disciplines and training future researchers, we not only advance knowledge but also contribute to the development of innovative technologies and therapeutic approaches.

 


Last Modified: 02/11/2024
Modified by: Mohammad Mofrad
